title: 108_hr487
content: The Military Selective Service Act is repealed. The Military Selective Service Act is repealed, and assets, contracts, property, and records of the Selective Service System will be transferred to the Administrator of General Services. The Office of Selective Service Records will not be reestablished, and employees will be assisted in transferring to other positions in the executive branch. Sanctions for persons previously subject to registration will be terminated. Registration under the Military Selective Service Act is no longer required by Federal law, and individuals cannot be denied rights or benefits for failing to register. Title 5 of the United States Code is amended to reflect this change. The Military Selective Service Act no longer requires registration, and individuals cannot be penalized for not registering. Amendments are made to Title 8 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Amendments are made to various sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act and Title 10 of the United States Code. This includes removing references to the Military Selective Service Act and making changes to specific clauses within the mentioned sections. Amendments are made to various sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act and Title 10 of the United States Code, including removing references to the Military Selective Service Act and making specific clause changes. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act and Title 10 of the United States Code include removing references to the Military Selective Service Act and making specific clause changes. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act and Title 10 of the United States Code involve removing mentions of the Military Selective Service Act and making specific clause adjustments. Amendments involve removing references to the Military Selective Service Act in various sections of the United States Code. Amendments involve updating the table of sections in chapter 1219 by replacing the item relating to section 12647. Amendments to various titles including Higher Education Act, Peace Corps Act, Internal Revenue Act, and Workforce Investment Act. Amendments to various sections in titles 36, 37, and 29 of the United States Code, including striking subsections, redesignating subsections, and amending specific paragraphs. Amendments to sections in Title 42 of the Social Security Act and the Legal Services Corporation Act regarding legal assistance for individuals provisionally accepted for duty. The Act provides legal assistance for proceedings related to desertion from the Armed Forces, with an effective date 180 days after enactment.
